CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 1, 1966, pg. 11B, reads: "Vote Drive Expert Backs Shapp - Marvin Evans, right who headed up the highly successful voter registration drive for the NAACP during the Goldwater campaign, has been retained as campaign coordinator for six predominately Negro wards in City of Pittsburgh under the auspices of the 'Citizens for Shapp' headquarters. Evans will be assisted by Harvey Lankford of the Thirteenth Ward, who is an organizer for Local 29 Building Service Union employees.  When Milton Shapp, the Democratic candidate for Governor, came to Pittsburgh last week, he is shown congratulating Evans on the job he is doing in an attempt to bring out the vote for Shapp's candidacy. - Harris Photo."Milton Shapp (1912-1994), candidate for the governorship of Pennsylvania, beside a white van with a poster reading "Teamsters Local 249, Labor for Shapp, governor, -- Staisey, Lt. governor, A.F.L.-C.I.O. - Teamsters, Vote Democratic."  Shapp and Staisey ran unsuccessfully on the Democratic ticket in 1966.  In 1971 Shapp ran with a different running mate and won the election.  He served as governor of Pennsylvania from 1971 to 1978.  Directly behind the van is the marquee for the Lowe's Penn Theatre, with the Mayflower Coffee Shop on the right.
TitMainTitle: Gubernatorial candidate Milton Shapp shaking hands with Marvin Evans beside campaign van, in front of Penn Theater and Mayflower Coffee Shop, Downtown
